awd_titl_txt: Controlled Nanoparticle Size Modifications and Functionalizations through controlled polymeric Nanonetwork Expansion
awd_abstract_narration:
Plastics that are composed from organic networks are one of the most widely used materials.  However, most polymer networks are difficult to manipulate once the material is formed.  The research group of Professor Eva Harth at the University of Houston aims to develop robust synthetic methods for the fabrication of tiny organic network structures (of dimensions much smaller than the width of hair) with the ability to modify a parent structure into various other networks of different sizes and functions.  The ability to add functions to, modify composition of, or expand the network to allow for repair would broaden the applications of nano-scale polymer networks.  This interdisciplinary project educates graduate and undergraduate students in STEM fields.  Rising high school seniors and seniors have the opportunity to engage in this research through the Welch Summer Scholars Program.

This project focuses on the preparation of photoresponsive nanomaterials and their manipulation in dimension, molecular weight and chemical functional groups. The research team of Professor Harth is establishing methods to synthesize photogrowable nanonetworks from a variety of degradable and non-degradable polymer backbones and cross-linking units containing trithiocarbonate units. Photoinduced polymerizations in the presence and absence of photoredox catalysts are utilized for the dynamic growth to expand the networks and introduce functional monomers into the existing schaffolds. Conditions of photo-controlled radical polymerizations for these expansion processes are thoroughly investigated as these determine the final dispersity of the network. Ultimately, this research is directed to test the capability and range of manipulation which is possible by applying photo-controlled radical polymerization techniques to generate the next generation of nano- and micron scale network materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The funded project aimed to investigate the controlled photo-expansion of cross-linked nano-networks. It was the goal to orthogonally direct both the extension of the polymer scaffold and the crosslinking unit. Four different types of intermolecular cross-linked networks were developed which include a cross-linking through Diels-Alder, acid-chloride and isocyanate-OH chemistries. The choice of the two components to facilitate the nanonetwork, the polyacrylate scaffold with pendant functional groups and the di-functional cross-linker predetermined the possible orthogonal expansion chemistries which were selective for the scaffold chain-end and the trithiocarbonate cross-linker.  In this fashion, selective chain extensions using ring-opening polymerization, orthogonal light-initiated reversible addition-fragmentation chain-transfer polymerization (RAFT) and atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) were realized. The project showed polymeric extensions of the cross-linking unit lead to controlled expansions of the nanoscopic size and extensions of the scaffold lead to additional molecular weight increase. It was demonstrated how light-initiated RAFT polymerization methods could be combined through the choice of redox complexes and wavelength of light. One of the challenges of the project involved the development of suitable cross-linking chemistries for the network generation which would guarantee the fidelity of the polymeric chain end of the polymeric scaffold as well as the livingness of the trithiocarbonate crosslinking unit.  Furthermore, synthetic challenges were mastered to enable an orthogonal expansion of the polymeric network of both the crosslinking unit and the scaffold of a polymer network by using the same type of controlled radical polymerization or through a combination of methods. The work will broaden the scope of possible synthetic manipulations of the polymer networks post their formation in the nanoscale and bulk. The project taught how controlled radical polymerization processes can be combined with and without light-initiation to achieve selective chain extensions of the crosslinking unit and the polymeric scaffold. Fundamental studies on the post-modification of polymeric networks proved the possibility to integrate functional groups and to change the polarity of the network which can be performed either at the polymer scaffold which will not change the network density or the crosslinking unit which results in an extension of the polymer network and is observed by a controlled change in the nanoscopic dimension.


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Eva M Harth
